results.title: Centre stage = Yuen Ling Yuk
results.creator_credit: Stanley Kwan, Willie Chan Chi Keung, Chui Siu Ming and Paragon Films
results.brief_description: Based on the real life of Chinese silent movie star Ruan Lingyu, ‘Centre Stage’ brings back to life the golden age of the ‘Hollywood of the East’, the Lienhau studios of Shanghai in the 1930s. Ruan (Maggie Cheung) is already an established star at age 20 when her world starts to collapse. First married to an immature, pleasure seeking play boy, she obtains a costly divorce in order to set-up house with Tang Chi Shan (Tony Leung Ka-fai), a producer at Lienhua who is also a married man. Tired of playing melodramatic characters, Ruan accepts a role in film directed by an up and coming director titled ‘New Woman’. The film is a vicious attack of the Chinese press whose tabloid style is pushing a woman to destruction. The press retaliates so violently that massive cuts are ordered to appease the anger of the opinion makers. This is the time Ruan’s ex-husband re-appears and threatens to expose her as an adulteress. Ruan’s star starts to spiral down. The film blends fact and fiction, documentary and narrative. Rare footage of the real Ruan’s performances are mixed with Cheung’s re-creations of Ruan’s lost films. In a clever twist of casting, the role of Ruan, originally intended for Anita Mui (Kwan’s star in ‘Rouge’), went to Maggie Cheung. Cheung was the same age as Ruan at the time of her suicide and had had many run-ins with the Hong Kong press. Kwan blends his narrative with documentary style footage of Cheung explaining how she researched the part and interviews with Chinese cinema veterans. The result is an interrogation on cinema itself. The film won several awards, including the Silver Bear for Best Actress at the 1992 Berlin Film Festival. Also stars Carina Lau, Waise Lee, Cecilia Yip. In Cantonese with English subtitles. The film is also known as ‘The Actress’, ‘The New China Woman’ in various English releases or ‘Ruan Ling-yu’ in Mandarin.

results.title: Centre court champions
results.creator_credit: Howard Rubie, British Petroleum and Cinesound
results.brief_description: Demonstrations of good play in tennis on a grass court and a hard court with comments by Harry Hopman. Emphasizes the need for good balance, skill in service, a great variety of strokes, and agile footwork; with some sequences in slow motion. Top Australian players are shown in action, including Tony Roche, John Newcombe, Owen Davidson and Lesley Turner. Concludes with the 1965 Australian Singles Finals, in black and white, with Roy Emerson and Fred Stolle.

results.title: Centralia
results.brief_description: Depicts scenic places around Alice Springs, Stanley’s Chasm, Hermannsburg, Ormiston Gorge, Glen Helen Gorge, Ayres Rock and The Olgas, and discusses the geology, history, living conditions and aboriginal mythology of the areas shown. Narrated by Ron Haddrick.
results.description: Depicts scenic places around Alice Springs, Stanley’s Chasm, Hermannsburg, Ormiston Gorge, Glen Helen Gorge, Ayres Rock and The Olgas, and discusses the geology, history, living conditions and aboriginal mythology of the areas shown. Narrated by Ron Haddrick.

results.title: Celebration of a nation
results.brief_description: Produced to celebrate Australia’s bicentenary in 1988, this short picture postcard presents images of Australia’s distinct landscape, flora and fauna, new Australian’s sharing their experiences, archival footage of the colonial era and Australian’s at war, natural disasters, and footage of the entertainment industry; music, dance, performance and radio. The soundtrack is a combination of Australian rock as well as instrumental “patriotic” songs.

results.title: Central experimental farm
results.creator_credit: Lawrence Cherry and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: Canada runs the largest system of experimental farms in the world. The headquarters of this system is the Dominion Experimental Farm in Ottawa, whose staff of experts is shown at work. Experts in plant nutrition, soil research, food preservation, animal husbandry, cereal improvements and the use of farm machinery are seen at work. In brief scenes we are told something about the aims of the Cereal Division, where scientists are working to produce better grades of wheat. Experiments in poultry breeding to increase egg production, tests of different varieties of commercial seed, and the development of better breeds of livestock are among the activities shown in other divisions. Farmers visit the farm and are given practical demonstrations of improved methods.

results.title: Celebrating Bird: the triumph of Charlie Parker
results.creator_credit: Pioneer Artists, Sony Video Software Company, Multiprises and Toby Byron
results.brief_description: Charlie Parker, famously known as Bird, won fame as the king of the hipsters with his virtuoso saxophone playing and innovative jazz. This work traces his life story from Kansas City to the New York jazz scene of the 1950s, tracing the short, somewhat tragic journey of a lauded and revered, if commercially ignored, musician. As well as providing key performances of signature tunes - Ballade, Yardbird Suite, Just friends, Koko, Confirmation, Au Privave and Kim Bloomdido - this work also comprises his only surviving TV performance, and interviews with Bird’s contemporaries. Contains wonderful vintage footage of Bird performing, plus tunes performed by Thelonious Monk, Louis Armstrong and Count Basie.

results.title: Cecil B. Demented
results.creator_credit: John Waters, Mark Tarlov, Joe Caracciolo Jr, John Fiedler, Artic Productions and Studio Canal
results.brief_description: John Water’s Cecil B Demented is an anarchic kick to the bloated carcus that is mainstream Hollywood feature films. No one escapes Waters’ skewered assault as he derides the mediocrity that now inhabits the American studio system. The plot is a compendium of Waters’ previous film work and favorite obsessions, offering up kidnapping, demented ciniphiles, scathing parodies (the highlight being the Forest Gump sequel, ‘Gumped again’) and highly specific sexual perversity. Steven Dorf stars as Cecil B Demented, the deranged leader of the ‘Sprocket Holes’, a gang of film fanatics hell bent on overthrowing the Hollywood A-list and out to “punish bad cinema”. Their insane plan involves kidnapping megalomanic movie star Honey Whitlock (Melanie Griffith relishing her role as the bitchy diva) and forcing her to appear in their own underground movie. What ensues is a wild parody of hollywood movie making, while Waters affectionately sends up his own days as a filmmaking terrorist. Cast includes: Alicia Witt, Mink Stole, Ricki Lake, Patricia Hearst, Adrien Grenier, Larry Gillard Jr.

results.title: Cat's cradle
results.creator_credit: Film Victoria, Swinburne Institute of Technology. Film and Television School, Liz Hughes, Chris McGill and Luigi Acquisto
results.brief_description:
The Father lies stiff and near-naked on the kitchen table. His family prepare his body for an outing to the cinema and then carry him through a bleak landscape of concrete roads and decaying factories. This short film combines highly expressionist black and white cinematography with an ominous atmospheric soundtrack. The result is a bizarre and perverse film that has the texture of a dream. Winner of multiple awards for Best Short Film, including prizes at the Melbourne, Edinburgh and London Film Festivals.
Cast includes Helen Rollinson, Ian Nash, Imogen Gough, Paul Bajada, Ryan Giddins and features William McInnes as an extra.

results.title: Centennial Park
results.creator_credit: Susan Doring, Don Murray and Film Australia
results.brief_description: A look at Centennial Park in Sydney - its beauty and history, its importance to wildlife and the use people make of it. Photographer: Ross King. Narrated by Tim Eliott.

results.title: Centaur
results.creator_credit: Susan Gibbard, Tom Daly and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: The camera-work, music and colours of this film combine to express the joy of horses and horsemanship. Filmed with members of the Canadian Equestrian Team and designed to capture the essence of the sport where horse and rider seem to move as one. (Awards: Reims, Yorkton, Chantilly)
